title: 115_s1607
content: The Act may be cited as the "Federal Highway Aid Performance-Based Improvement Act of 2017" and includes a pilot program. The "Federal Highway Aid Performance-Based Improvement Act of 2017" includes a pilot program called the Consolidated Funding Pilot Program to transform the Federal-aid highway program to focus on performance and outcome-based projects in 3 selected States. The "Federal Highway Aid Performance-Based Improvement Act of 2017" aims to streamline program categories for the Federal-aid highway program, providing additional flexibility to States for investment decisions. The implementation involves apportioning funds to eligible States, with set-asides for entities other than the State transportation department. The "Federal Highway Aid Performance-Based Improvement Act of 2017" consolidates transportation department apportionment programs into a single program. Eligible activities include those under individual apportionment programs. States must demonstrate performance management systems for safety and infrastructure to participate in the program. The "Federal Highway Aid Performance-Based Improvement Act of 2017" requires states to have performance management systems with metrics to guide the use of program funds and prioritize projects. States must also show progress towards national goals for congestion reduction, system reliability, and freight movement/economic vitality. The "Federal Highway Aid Performance-Based Improvement Act of 2017" mandates states to establish performance management systems with metrics to allocate program funds and prioritize projects. States must demonstrate progress towards national goals for congestion reduction, system reliability, and economic vitality. The Secretary will implement the program for a minimum of 6 years, focusing on environmental sustainability, reduced project delivery delays, and collaboration with relevant agencies. The Secretary will implement the program for at least 6 years. Participation of a State may be terminated if the Secretary determines noncompliance and provides a 30-day corrective action period. The State may be terminated from participation in the program if satisfactory corrective action is not taken within the specified period. States can also terminate their participation by providing notice to the Secretary and complying with additional terms if required. Participating States must submit an annual report demonstrating the use of performance management systems in decision-making. The State's transportation improvement program must use performance management systems for decision-making and report progress to Congress annually. Consolidated funding pilot program.
